metadata.title: Immobilized chiral Mn(III) salen complexes on co-condensed imidazole-functionalized mesoporous materials: Effective catalysts for asymmetric epoxidation of olefins
metadata.journal: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical

Immobilized chiral Mn(III) salen complexes on co-condensed imidazole-functionalized mesoporous materials: Effective catalysts for asymmetric epoxidation of olefins Lan-Lan Lou a Huanling Du a Kai Yu b Shu Jiang a Wenjun Yu a Shuangxi Liu a ⁎ a Institute of New Catalytic Materials Science and Key Laboratory of Advanced Energy Materials Chemistry (Ministry of Education), College of Chemistry, Nankai University, Tianjin 300071, China Institute of New Catalytic Materials Science and Key Laboratory of Advanced Energy Materials Chemistry (Ministry of Education), College of Chemistry, Nankai University Tianjin 300071 China b College of Environmental Science and Engineering, Nankai University, Tianjin 300071, China College of Environmental Science and Engineering, Nankai University Tianjin 300071 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 22 23509005; fax: +86 22 23509005. Graphical abstract The heterogeneous chiral Mn(III) salen catalysts with ordered hexagonal mesostructure were prepared based on mesoporous materials functionalized by imidazole groups through a co-condensation procedure. These catalysts were highly active and enantioselective for the asymmetric epoxidation of olefins. Within a short reaction time, comparable conversion and enantiomeric excess to those of the homogeneous counterpart were obtained even with a very low catalyst dosage (0.60mol%). Thus notably high turnover frequencies (up to 165h−1) were provided by these catalysts, attributed in part to the homogeneous distribution of the active centers as well as the strong electron-donating ability of imidazole groups. Comparison experiments showed that these catalysts were twice more active than the catalysts supported on the mesoporous material graft-modified with imidazole. Furthermore, the nanopore size of mesoporous hybrid supports was found to have a considerable effect on the catalytic performance. Keywords Chiral Mn(III) salen complex Co-condensation Imidazole-modified mesoporous material Asymmetric epoxidation Pore size 1 Introduction Chiral Mn(III) salen complexes have proven to be highly efficient homogeneous catalysts for the enantioselective epoxidation of olefins [1–3], which are of high significance in the synthesis of a variety of valuable chiral intermediates in the pharmaceutical and agrochemical fields. However, the difficulties in product separation and catalyst recovery under homogeneous system often hinder their practical applications. Heterogenization of homogeneous catalyst is one of the most promising strategies to overcome these problems; therefore, the heterogenization of chiral Mn(III) salen complexes has received recently great attention [4–11]. Considerable researches have centered on the immobilization of chiral Mn(III) salen complexes onto solid supports such as organic polymers [12–16] and porous inorganic supports [17–27]. Recently, the silica-based mesoporous materials have attracted extensive attention for the immobilization of chiral Mn(III) salen complexes [20–27] owing to their high surface areas, large and tunable pore size, as well as easy organical functionalization. In most cases, the organosilanes that are acting as linkage groups between mesoporous material and chiral Mn(III) salen complex were anchored onto the surface of silica matrix by a postsynthetic grafting method, which is a commonly used pathway for the synthesis of porous hybrid materials. However, in this way the organic groups would be preferentially grafted on the external surface and near the pore openings, leading to a nonuniform distribution of the organic linkage groups within the mesopores. Thus a significantly high catalyst/substrate ratio and a longer reaction time were often demanded over the grafted Mn(III) salen catalysts, resulting in relatively low turnover frequencies (TOFs). It is therefore highly desirable to develop a more active heterogeneous Mn(III) salen catalyst. Co-condensation (one-pot synthesis) is an alternative method to synthesize organically functionalized mesoporous materials. For the materials prepared through this method, the organic units are generally more homogeneously distributed than in materials synthesized by grafting [28–31] because the organosilica fragments were direct components of the matrix. At the same time, pore blocking could be effectively avoided in these hybrid materials [28]. Therefore, the silica-based mesoporous organic–inorganic hybrid materials prepared via co-condensation should be excellent matrixes for immobilization of chiral catalysts, which would lead to more uniform distribution and thus more effective utilization of the active centers. In this work, a series of imidazole-functionalized MCM-41-type mesoporous materials were synthesized through co-condensation of tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) and N-(3-triethoxysilylpropyl)imidazole (TESPI), and were used to immobilize chiral Mn(III) salen complex. The as-synthesized catalysts showed excellent catalytic activity and enantioselectivity, as expected, in the asymmetric epoxidation of olefins even with a relatively low catalyst amount. Compared with the catalysts prepared by grafting method, the present catalysts are twice more active. Besides, these catalysts can complete epoxidation rapidly, due in part to the strong electron-donating ability of imidazole groups. Thus notably high TOFs were achieved over these heterogeneous catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials m-Chloroperbenzoic acid (m-CPBA) was purchased from Acros Organics. 3-Chloropropyltriethoxysilane, N-methylmorpholine-N-oxide (NMO), and α-methylstyrene were provided by Aldrich. Indene was obtained from Fluka. Styrene, TEOS (AR), and ammonia (25wt.%, AR) were supplied by Jiangtian Chemical Technology Co., Ltd. in Tianjin. Alkyltrimethylammonium bromide C n H2n+1(CH3)3-NBr (C n TAB for brevity, n =14, 16, and 18; AR) was purchased from Jintan Huadong Chemical Research Institute in Jiangsu. TESPI was synthesized from the reaction of 3-chloropropyltriethoxysilane and imidazole as reported in the literature [32]. The chiral Mn(III) salen complex 1 was prepared as described previously [33]. 2.2 Characterization ICP-AES analyses were conducted on an ICP-9000(N+M) spectrometer (TJA Co.). Elemental analysis was carried out on a Perkin–Elmer 240C analyzer. Powder XRD patterns were obtained on an Rigaku D/max-2500 diffractometer with CuKα radiation at 40kV and 100mA. N2 adsorption–desorption analysis was carried out at 77K on a Micromeritics TriStar 3000 apparatus. The surface area was determined using the BET equation, and the pore size distribution was estimated by the BJH model. FT-IR spectra were collected on a Bruker Vector 22 spectrometer using KBr pellets in the 400–4000cm−1 region. Diffuse reflectance UV–vis (DR UV–vis) spectra of the solid samples were recorded on a ZASCOV-570 UV–vis spectrophotometer with an integrating sphere using BaSO4 as standard. TEM measurements were performed on a Philips Tecnai G2F20 apparatus operated at an accelerating voltage of 120kV. The products of the epoxidation reaction were detected by gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with a flame ionization detector. 2.3 Catalyst preparation 2.3.1 Synthesis of immobilized chiral catalyst based on co-condensation method The imidazole-modified mesoporous materials were synthesized through co-condensation of TEOS and TESPI using C n TAB (n =14, 16, and 18) as template. A gel with a molar composition of 1.0Si:0.12C n TAB:8.0NH4OH:114H2O was adopted, in which the Si source was composed of TEOS and TESPI. In a typical synthesis, to the solution of C n TAB in water ammonia was added under vigorous stirring. Then the required quantities of TEOS and TESPI were added dropwise into the solution. After stirring for additional 0.5h, the resulting gel was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave heated at 383K for a certain time. The solid product was filtered off, washed with deionized water, dried in air, and finally Soxhlet-extracted with an acidic ethanol solution for 72h to remove the template. The as-synthesized materials were denoted as C n M(x) (n =14, 16, and 18; x =1, 2.5, 5, and 7.5), where x(%) represents the molar ratio of TESPI to total Si. The synthesis process of heterogeneous catalyst is shown in Scheme 1 . The obtained mesoporous material C n M(x) (1.0g) and chiral Mn(III) salen complex 1 (0.12g) were refluxed in toluene (50mL) for 24h. After cooled to room temperature, the brown solid product was recovered by filtration, washed with dichloromethane, and then Soxhlet-extracted with acetone for 24h. The obtained heterogeneous catalysts were designated as C n M(x)-1 (n =14, 16, 18). 2.3.2 Synthesis of immobilized chiral catalyst based on grafting method For comparison, the chiral Mn(III) salen catalysts immobilized on the hybrid mesoporous materials prepared by the grafting method were also synthesized. Firstly, the highly ordered siliceous mesoporous material MCM-41 was synthesized according to the literature methods [34,35] using TEOS as silica source and C16TAB as template. Then, the calcined siliceous MCM-41 (1.0g) and TESPI (0.1g, 0.2g, or 0.3g) were stirred in 50mL of anhydrous chloroform. After refluxed for 20h, the solid powder was collected by filtration, washed thoroughly with chloroform and diethyl ether, and dried. The product was marked as GM(y) (y =0.1, 0.2, 0.3). Finally, this hybrid mesoporous material was reacted with Mn(III) salen complex 1 by following the same procedure as mentioned above to generate the heterogeneous catalyst GM(y)-1. The contents of imidazole groups in the functionalized supports, determined by elemental analysis, were 0.20, 0.36 and 0.49mmolg−1 for GM(0.1), GM(0.2) and GM(0.3), respectively. The loadings of Mn(III) salen complex 1, determined by ICP-AES based on the element Mn, were 0.09, 0.12 and 0.14mmolg−1 for GM(0.1)-1, GM(0.2)-1 and GM(0.3)-1, respectively. Correspondingly, the contents of imidazole groups in C16M(2.5) and C16M(5) were 0.38 and 0.69mmolg−1, respectively. And the amount of Mn(III) salen complex 1 was 0.035mmolg−1 for C16M(2.5)-1 and C16M(5)-1. 2.4 Asymmetric epoxidation of olefins Asymmetric epoxidation reactions were carried out using the catalyst (0.006mmol, 0.60mol%, based on Mn element) with styrene, α-methylstyrene and indene as substrates (1mmol) in the presence of m-CPBA (2mmol) as oxidant and NMO (5mmol) as axial base in dichloromethane (10mL) at 273K. Conversions (with toluene as an internal standard) and enantiomeric excess (ee) values were determined by GC using a chiral capillary column (RESTEK RT-BetaDEXse, 30m×0.25mm×0.25μm) with the column temperature programmed in the range of 333–423K. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of materials The influence of crystallization time on the synthesis of mesoporous materials C n M(x) was studied. Fig. 1 displays the representative XRD patterns of C16M(5) samples synthesized by changing crystallization time from 48 to 84h. All the patterns of samples showed three peaks at (100), (110) and (200) reflections, confirming that 2D hexagonal phase formed. An increase in intensity of corresponding peaks was observed as the crystallization time was increased from 48h to 72h, implying that the long-range order of the mesostructure enhanced. Further increase of crystallization time, however, had a negative effect on the mesopore ordering of the produced sample. All C n M(x) samples synthesized with a crystallization time of 72h revealed highly ordered 2D hexagonal mesoporous structure in light of the observation of diffraction peaks corresponding to (100), (110) and (200) reflections. As Fig. 2 displays, with the increase in the relative amount of TESPI in the synthesis mixture, the relative intensities of XRD peaks decreased gradually, which indicated that the long-range mesoporous ordering of these hybrid materials was dependent on the relative amount of organosilane. After the immobilization of chiral Mn(III) salen complex 1, a marginal decrease in the relative intensities of the XRD reflections was observed. The well-resolved (110) and (200) reflections for C n M(x)-1 (Fig. 3 ) indicates that the immobilization treatment had little influence on the mesostructure of C n M(x). Moreover, with the increase in alkyl chain length of the template, the XRD reflections of C n M(x)-1 were shifted to lower 2θ values, which implied that the pore size of heterogeneous catalysts increased gradually. In addition, the grafted catalyst GM(0.2)-1 also possessed typical 2D-hexagonal mesostructure, as shown in Fig. 3c, exhibiting three distinct diffraction peaks assigned to (100), (110) and (200) reflections. N2 physisorption experiments showed that all the mesoporous supports C n M(x) and heterogeneous catalysts C n M(x)-1 exhibited type IV adsorption–desorption isotherms [36] and narrow pore size distributions, suggesting that the mesoporous structure of support materials was maintained after immobilization of complex 1. From the textural parameters listed in Table 1 , it could be noted that with the increase in alkyl chain length of the template, the pore diameter of C n M(5) and C n M(5)-1 increased. This was accordant with the results of XRD characterization. Compared with the corresponding parent supports, C16M(5)-1 and C18M(5)-1 showed decreased BET surface area, pore volume, and pore size, demonstrating that the chiral Mn(III) salen complex 1 was grafted mainly inside the channels of support materials. While a marginal decrease in textural parameters was observed after immobilization of complex 1 on C14M(5), which may be explained by that relatively less amount of chiral Mn(III) salen complex was loaded on the inner surface in C14M(5)-1 attributed to the higher diffusional resistance of C14M(5). FTIR and DR UV–vis spectra of the immobilized catalysts were observed to mutually agree with the expected chemical structure of the free Mn(III) salen complex. As can be noticed in Fig. 4 , the presence of the characteristic band of Mn(III) salen complex at 1545cm−1 [37,38] and the obvious increase of the intensities of the IR bands near 2900 and 1400cm−1 attributed to CH vibrations of alkyl groups confirmed the successful incorporation of chiral Mn(III) salen complex 1 onto the co-condensed mesoporous supports. Fig. 4 also shows the FTIR spectra in the scan range of 1300–3200cm−1 for C16M(5) before and after template removal. The intensities of the bands at 2962, 2926, 2856 and 1478cm−1 assigned to the existence of C16TAB aggregates significantly decreased after extraction, implying that the surfactant has been almost completely removed. The DR UV–vis spectra of free complex and immobilized catalyst C16M(5)-1 are given in Fig. 5 . The spectrum of C16M(5)-1 shows features similar to those of the free complex. The bands at 259 and 332nm can be due to the charge transfer transition of salen ligand, and the bands at 438 and 510nm are assigned to ligand-to-metal charge transfer transition and the d–d transition of Mn(III) salen complex, respectively. On immobilization, a blue shift was observed for these bands, probably due to the interaction between the Mn(III) salen complex and the support. TEM micrographs of the heterogeneous catalyst C16M(5)-1 (Fig. 6 ) revealed a regular hexagonal array of the mesochannels with uniform pore size. This evidenced that the hexagonally ordered mesostructure of the support material was maintained by the immobilization of Mn(III) salen complex. The TEM results are basically accordant with that acquired from XRD and N2 sorption analysis discussed above. 3.2 Catalytic studies The as-synthesized heterogeneous catalysts C n M(x)-1 were evaluated in the epoxidation of olefins. The effects of catalyst amount, reaction time and TESPI dosage on the catalytic activity and enantioselectivity were investigated, and the results are summarized in Table 2 . Control experiment showed no observable epoxidation reaction by the supports C n M(x). As the catalyst amount was increased from 0.35 to 0.60mol%, there was a significant enhancement in styrene conversion and product ee value. Comparable catalytic activity and enantioselectivity (93% conversion and 43% ee) to homogeneous results could be obtained by C16M(5)-1 as the catalyst amount reached 0.60mol%. Similar phenomenon was found for relatively bulkier olefins, like indene. An ee value of 84% was achieved by C16M(5)-1 at a low catalyst amount of 0.60mol% with a high indene conversion of 98%. This indicated that the active sites in the channels of immobilized catalyst could also be accessed readily by the bulkier substrate. It should be pointed out that the catalyst amount used in the present work (0.60mol%) was much lower than the reported work [17–24,26]. It was also found that the catalytic performance increased with prolonging reaction time from 0.5 to 1h. However, no obvious improvement was observed with a further increase in reaction time even to 8h (entries 2 and 10). This signified that the epoxidation reactions over the immobilized catalysts C n M(x)-1 proceeded rapidly and approached completion within 1h. Thus, extraordinarily high turnover frequencies (TOFs, e.g., 153h−1 for C16M(5)-1 in styrene epoxidation) were provided by the present catalysts C n M(x)-1, which were comparable to those for homogeneous catalyst 1 and even orders of magnitude higher than those of the catalysts based on the similar supports reported in the literature [20–22,26,27]. In the heterogeneous catalyst, TESPI serves as a covalent linker between the chiral complex 1 and mesoporous support. Hence TESPI would play a central role in the loading of complex 1 and the catalytic performance of immobilized catalysts. As listed in Table 2, the catalysts C16M(2.5)-1 and C16M(5)-1 exhibited rather good catalytic performances, and comparable conversions and ee values to the homogeneous counterpart were achieved for styrene epoxidation. As the TESPI dosage increased to 7.5mol%, the corresponding catalyst provided obviously lower activities and enantioselectivities. This may be explained by the fact that the catalyst C16M(7.5)-1 possessed relatively smaller pore size, which resulted in the increased diffusional resistance and thus made some of the active centers located in the pore channels of heterogeneous catalyst unapproachable. For the purpose of comparison, the catalytic reaction results of heterogeneous catalyst GM(y)-1, which was synthesized by sequential grafting of TESPI and Mn(III) salen complex on siliceous mesoporous MCM-41, are also given in Table 2. It could be seen that GM(0.2)-1 exhibited higher activity and enantioselectivity than the other two grafted catalysts. With a catalyst dosage of 1.5mol% under otherwise identical reaction conditions, 90% conversion and 42% ee value were achieved by GM(0.2)-1 (entry 15). While the catalyst amount decreased to 0.60mol%, only 56% conversion and 22% ee were obtained (entry 16). For further comparison, a control experiment was performed that less amount of Mn(III) salen complex was supported on mesoporous material GM(0.2) and the as-synthesized catalyst was denoted as GM(0.2)-1(L), which possessed similar loadings of imidazole group and Mn(III) salen complex with C16M(2.5)-1. The catalyst GM(0.2)-1(L) was evaluated in the epoxidation of styrene with a catalyst dosage of 0.60mol%. As given in Table 2, obviously lower catalytic activity and enantioselectivity (35% conversion and 13% ee) than those of C16M(2.5)-1 were obtained (entry 18). These results confirmed the fact that co-condensation method was effective and favorable to the preparation of heterogeneous chiral catalysts, and the as-synthesized catalysts, such as C16M(5)-1 and C16M(2.5)-1, were twice more active than the normally grafted catalyst. The reason for the dramatic decrease in amount of heterogeneous catalyst may be that the active centers were more homogeneously distributed on the surface of co-condensed materials C n M(x), which would lead to more ready accessibility and effective utilization of the active sites, and thus to improved catalytic performance. For comparison, the catalytic results of the chiral Mn(III) salen catalyst immobilized on the 3-aminopropyl-containing mesoporous material synthesized through co-condensation (marked as NH2-C16M(5)-1) are also listed in Table 2. It could be found that the co-condensed catalyst NH2-C16M(5)-1 can also provide rather high conversion and ee value under a low catalyst amount of 0.60mol%, however, much longer reaction time (8h) was required to reach reaction completion (entry 19). Thus the imidazole-based catalyst C16M(5)-1 exhibited significantly higher TOF than that of NH2-C16M(5)-1. This fact may be explained by the two following reasons. Firstly, the stronger electron-donating ability of imidazole groups in C n M(x)-1 would facilitate the nucleophilical attack of the oxygen atom of OMn(V) salen on the olefin substrate. Secondly, the rigid structure of imidazole ring would allow the catalytic active sites located inside the mesoporous channels to be more accessible by the substrate molecules. The pore sizes of the heterogeneous catalysts were varied through altering the alkyl chain length of the template during the synthesis of mesoporous supports C n M(x). The representative series of catalysts C n M(5)-1 with different pore sizes were evaluated in the asymmetric epoxidation of styrene, α-methylstyrene and indene. As Table 3 displays, the catalytic activity and enantioselectivity increased obviously with gently increasing the nanopore sizes of heterogeneous catalysts. The catalysts C16M(5)-1 and C18M(5)-1 showed comparable conversions and ee values to those of homogeneous counterpart. Especially, C18M(5)-1 provided the highest catalytic performance among these heterogeneous catalysts (entries 6, 10 and 16); for example, 99% conversion and 85% ee for indene were obtained. This could be attributed to the larger pore size of C18M(5)-1, which would facilitate the material transmission. While the catalyst C14M(5)-1, which possessed the smallest pore size, exhibited evidently lower conversion and ee value (entries 2, 8 and 14). This may be explained by that the relatively smaller pore size for C14M(5) would hinder complex 1 from being loaded into the channels, and accordingly the distribution of active centers in C14M(5)-1 was less uniform than that in C16M(5)-1 and C18M(5)-1. In a word, the catalytic performance of these heterogeneous catalysts was bound up with the pore sizes; the catalyst possessing larger pore size would give better activity and enantioselectivity. To assess the stability of the immobilized catalysts during the epoxidation of olefin, the filtrate after reaction was detected by ICP-AES. No obvious Mn leaching (<1%) was found for the heterogeneous catalysts C n M(x)-1, which indicated that the chiral Mn(III) salen complex 1 was strongly anchored on the mesoporous supports C n M(x). To further confirm that the epoxidation reaction is indeed catalyzed by the solid catalyst, the catalyst C16M(5)-1 was filtrated after 0.25h (ca. 68% styrene conversion) and the filtrate was stirred continuously under the same reaction temperature. No increase in the conversion and ee value was observed even prolonging the reaction time to 3h (entries 4 and 5 in Table 3). Thus it can be concluded that the observed catalysis is predominantly heterogeneous. Whereas the recycling experiments showed that the catalyst C18M(5)-1 provided progressive reductions of conversion and ee during the three recycling runs (entries 10–12 in Table 3). This may be caused by that some of the catalytic active sites in the solid catalyst are covered by entrapped reactants and excessive oxidant during the reaction. 4 Conclusion The chiral Mn(III) salen complex was successfully supported on the imidazole-modified mesoporous materials synthesized via co-condensation. These heterogeneous catalysts exhibited excellent catalytic activity and enantioselectivity even with a relatively low catalyst amount (0.60mol%) within a short reaction time (1h), thus providing notably high TOF values, due in part to the homogeneous distribution of the active centers as well as the strong electron-donating ability of imidazole groups. The nanopore size of mesoporous support was found to have a great influence on catalytic performance. The catalyst C18M(5)-1 with larger pore size showed the best catalytic activity and enantioselectivity for olefin epoxidation. Acknowledgments This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (grant 21203102), the National High Technology Research and Development Program of China (grant 2012AA063008), the Specialized Research Fund for the Doctoral Program of Higher Education (grant 20100031120029), and 111 Project (B12015). coredata.dc:description: The heterogeneous chiral Mn(III) salen catalysts with ordered hexagonal mesostructure were prepared based on mesoporous materials functionalized by imidazole groups through a co-condensation procedure. These catalysts were highly active and enantioselective for the asymmetric epoxidation of olefins. Within a short reaction time, comparable conversion and enantiomeric excess to those of the homogeneous counterpart were obtained even with a very low catalyst dosage (0.60mol%). Thus notably high turnover frequencies (up to 165h−1) were provided by these catalysts, attributed in part to the homogeneous distribution of the active centers as well as the strong electron-donating ability of imidazole groups. Comparison experiments showed that these catalysts were twice more active than the catalysts supported on the mesoporous material graft-modified with imidazole. Furthermore, the nanopore size of mesoporous hybrid supports was found to have a considerable effect on the catalytic performance.
coredata.dc:title: Immobilized chiral Mn(III) salen complexes on co-condensed imidazole-functionalized mesoporous materials: Effective catalysts for asymmetric epoxidation of olefins
